comments.commentBody:
I think what college graduates are seeing today in the job market is not a temporary statistical dip in the employment numbers that will improve as the economy gets better. What we're seeing today is the reality of what the American economy really looks like in the absence of the kind of delusional credit and stock market bubbles we've been living off of for the last 20 years.

As the dust finally settles, we finally see the true impact of what 30 years of eroding union power, factories moved over seas, rampant outsourcing, and the callus disregard by top management for ordinary (and now not so ordinary) worker, has reaped upon the American way of life.

It's time for these young graduates to put down their brooms and start to organize a movement to bring about the real kind of change we need in this country cause it's clear Obama ain't gonna do it for them.
In 2o years of being in business for myself, only once did someone ask about a degree. I out-earn college grads, so what am I to say? Sorry.

IMHO a large part of the problem is that "going to college" is far too frequently confused with "a passion for learning".  The former can be a great catalyst for the latter... but the latter is [by itself] perfectly sufficient for achieving success.

This story gives the false impression that education does not help.

Yes, graduating with a degree may not be enough to get a good job. You have to keep learning on the job and on your own. You have to work at selling yourself to an employer.

I believe that the more you learn the more you will eventually earn. More brains equal more gains, in the long run.

I think that Pres. Obama should be pushing the link between education and economy, or EDU-CONOMY constantly. If not, he may not get re-elected.

See blog: EconomyWiseUp.com THANKS/Harry@RochesterNY

I'm definitely on the lower end of lower-middle class, but I'm able to cling to a decent apartment in an affluent neighborhood in Chicago, thanks to an editorial job I've suffered through for 10 years.  The other day I wanted to treat myself to a half-hour massage.  I couldn't find a single available slot within a week.  I cringe at these dire job reports from the Times, but when I look around my city, it seems people have more money (or credit) and jobs than they know what to do with.

Something left out of this article is the importance of the career placement office at the college.  Both of my children happened to go to the same college that has a career placement program ranked in the top ten by the WSJ. (Measured by placement in elite graduate programs, top fellowships, and challenging jobs). Every graduate needs help. The degree alone is not enough. My children have both been employed in good jobs since graduation, have got promotions, and been able to move on to better opportunities as their experience allowed.  But it all started with the assistance of the career placement office. Before a student decides on which college to attend, check into their respective career placement programs.

I recall my own disappointment after graduation decades ago. I would think I had a job and then it would not happen. I get lectures about not pushing to fast or too much for change or criticism for leaving ministry to work in a secular world. The pain remains.

One other thing to mention: One part of the bleak job market is companies taking tax breaks and sending jobs overseas. This is wrong; it's morally wrong. The government should (1) not give any kind of tax breaks for any company which sends jobs overseas and (2) give preferential treatment for companies which either do not export jobs, decrease the number of exported jobs, or have no exported jobs. This should be for all levels of government but especially local governments, state governments. There is no reason I should pay for some giant company to send jobs overseas.

Like so many members of my generation, I am in graduate school. Luckily, my program fits with my career goals, but too many of my friends have been forced into graduate programs--often incurring large amounts of debt--in the hopes that obtaining an MA or an MBA or a JD will raise their job prospects from dire to only somewhat hopeless. However, with the market for lawyers saturated, options in academia for PhDs dire (across virtually all disciplines), and most MA programs offering little boost in one's qualifications, it seems like the only "sure bet" left is medical school or becoming an engineer. Both of those are honorable options, but what happened to having choices?

Speaking as someone with three degrees -- and as the editor of a magazine I built myself -- I find all these anti-education comments extremely sad, but also stupid. If people don't understand anything about the world, how are they going to change it, fix it or improve it? When I get job applications, I never hire the business student, and I always hire the philosophy student. Why is that? - because the philosophy student is a better magazine writer, because they have spent time thinking about society. This idea -- the idea of an intellectual -- is something that our competitor countries understand.  France always understood it, but now I think even China and India understand the success of a society more than we do.  There is a reason half my fellow students for my M.A. in liberal arts were Chinese -- and it's not because they were rich -- it's because the Chinese understand the value of education.  China is becoming us, and we are becoming some dumbed-down third-world country.  If kids are working in Starbucks it's because they did not see the value of what they were learning.  While, sure, college graduates are having a time right now, that is not a reason for everyone to go and study engineering.  When we kill the liberal arts, we lose the ideas that made America great.  Case closed.
In my previous post I meant to say that when index funds are used in a 401(k) or 403(b) plan, the cost has got to be low.

I recently graduated from the University of Colorado with a BS in Finance, a BA in Economics, and a certificate in quantitative finance. So far, in my job hunt, I have found there to be an adequate supply of jobs. However, they predominantly require advanced degrees or 4+ years of professional experience. A decade ago, with my qualifications, I would have been a shoo-in to most financial analyst jobs. Today's market requires graduate degrees or professional experience. I can't get hired because I am not able to get that experience, and I don't wish to put myself in further servitude to my debtors. I have 40K in undergrad debt, so graduate school is not appealing at this point in time. I am optimistic, but it can be discouraging to spend two hours on an application only to never hear anything in response, or slightly less bad receive a generic rejection letter. It's tough people...

Attention recent college graduates (and their parents): The America of 1945-1990 can never be resurrected. If you want to get into publishing and writing (like Mr. Bishop from the article), write something, and publish it yourself! Sure, unless you write a vampire story you probably won't make any money, but the point is that, now, you'll be paid exactly what the public thinks you're writing is worth. No more hiding behind the logo of a big company. No more direct deposits of the same amount every week whether or not you did a good job. The 20th Century is over and the 21st Century is bare knuckles, two tarantulas in a bottle, (insert your favorite analogy here).

There is no more room in our economy for the 5th-best salesperson, or a slightly above-average computer programmer. The challenge our society faces, and our politicians must address, is what happens to the 97 or 98% of Americans who are below the elite level in whatever they are attempting to do?

The main problem seems to be that there is no 'role' for young people in this society. College is a way to keep them out of the labor force so that wages for their elders remain stable and secure. Alas, this system is rapidly falling into obsolescence. I feel for these young people, but I've been there, too. It's tough to make a start. Good luck, and don't forget that it's not your fault.

I graduated from university in the very late 1970's and like these current graduates, could not find a job though I had sent out 130 resumes across the country. Please understand that at this time, the job market for women was extremely limited. In despair, I entered secretarial school where I learned typing and stenography and promptly got a job in an advertising agency. By working ten and twelve hour days for very little pay, I learned job skills for entree level positions in the company and after a year, was promoted.

I have had a very successful and lucrative career and have decided to return to school for my master's degree. I'd like to change careers to an area that has fascinated me. In accepting offers, I decided to attend an ivy league. Brand is important.

In short, I think where you attend college, personal ambition and tenacity, matter. University should be a time of learning. This means you need to use the facilities to learn important skills that can enhance your future. Things like writing, reading books other than those required by courses and taking courses to advance learning. Social activities must come dead last. Until those priorities are embraced, college should be delayed. Perhaps our wise sages understood it best, "youth is wasted on the young."

The truth is that high school degrees today are pretty much worthless.  Too many high school graduates aren't even ready for "watered-down" college as one reader put it.  Therefore, you need that college degree even to advance at Walmart.  At the same time, the US has lost so many jobs to other countries due to CEO's greediness here that even low-wage jobs are disappearing.  I thought I was unlucky when I graduated right before the big crash of 1987.  Today I'm feeling pretty fortunate.

outsourcing + recession = resructured job landscape

Bush tax dollars are being invested overseas or parked offshore, not creating innovation or jobs here.

My children's Ivy League friends can not get jobs. They are hard working, some speak a number of languages, and have great credentials. The number of middle class jobs has decreased significantly since 2000.

The rules have changed when even the Simpson's animations are done in Korea. I tried to make a reservation at a Hampton Court a few weeks ago via their 800 number. I requested to talk to someone at the hotel site in Maine as I was traveling with my very disabled son. I was told that would be against their policy. I requested again
only to be told I was being rude. We will be staying at a different hotel.

I do not want to talk to reservation clerks in the Philippines, tech reps in India, nor do I want my medications processed in China. We don't need tariffs to demand that some of these functions done overseas that are currently done poorly be brought home. We would all be better served if corporations were not focused on decreasing their US workforce.

Eh, every generation has it's problems. When I graduated, I couldn't get a job because I didn't have "experience". Then, about 15 years later, "experience" didn't matter. Welcome to the working world.

Our children's desire to learn has become an opportunity to enslave them with debt. Everything, from our kids' aspirations to the failing health of our elders has turned into a soulless grab for financial gain. When are the American people going to wake up to the fact that the dream has turned into a nightmare? When are we going to reclaim our country from the plutocrats?

My daughter has had chronic sinusitis since she was four months old. We've been to every ENT and Allergist around. We've put tubes in her ears 2x. It has impacted her hearing negatively. It is a nightmare for her and I'm glad to know research is being done. We do a sinus rinse twice a day and that does help, but she still gets infections in the fall and winter months. Constant. She has a high pain tolerance so that makes it easier on her than most. Horrible.

N-acetylcysteine inhibits biofilms produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20462423 No rx needed. Can be taken orally, although might be more useful directly, eg. "Mucomyst".

What else? Singulaire might increase sinus infections: see:
Effect of montelukast on bacterial sinusitis in allergic mice.
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17042138
Very effective anti-asthma medicine, but it curtails some immune functions as well.

Sinus rinsing by Neti-pot or other means doesn't work for everyone, so I'm glad the pharmaceutical industry and medical researchers are able to provide other solutions. I don't mind paying for meds that mean I can walk without wheezing and actually breathe through my nose.

Many individuals get seasonal allergies and believe that the barometric pressure changes, pollen and or mold are the cause. We have had clients tested only to find that they are not allergic to any airborne allergen.  After IgE testing what we find is that they are sensitive to specific foods.  When the body is chronically inflammed by foods this may go systemic causing amongst other symptoms, sinusitis.  It is also thought that the weakened immune system becomes overwhelmed by seasonal changes; thus the thought process that it is airborne related.
I irrigated my sinuses for a while, but discovered I was getting sick MORE often. It doesn't work for everyone.
has anyone found that infected nose polyps are related to this?? i have been taking steroids and antibiotics for nose congestion, and now may have to have the polyps removed -
